recommendations.section: Organization of Prehospital and Initial Systems
recommendations.text: Public education programs targeting diverse populations are recommended to promote early stroke recognition (including spontaneous ICH) and prompt activation of emergency services, thereby reducing time to diagnosis and treatment.

recommendations.section: Organization of Prehospital and Initial Systems
recommendations.text: Validated stroke recognition and severity assessment tools are recommended for use by dispatch personnel and first responders to identify potential spontaneous ICH and facilitate rapid transport to an appropriate facility.

recommendations.section: Organization of Prehospital and Initial Systems
recommendations.text: Immediate activation of the emergency response system (e.g., 9-1-1) is recommended for patients with symptoms suggestive of spontaneous ICH to minimize time to diagnosis and treatment.

recommendations.section: Organization of Prehospital and Initial Systems
recommendations.text: Early prehospital notification by EMS to the receiving hospital is recommended for patients with suspected spontaneous ICH to improve time to diagnosis and treatment.

recommendations.section: Organization of Prehospital and Initial Systems
recommendations.text: Regional stroke systems of care are recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH, including facilities capable of initial ICH diagnosis and treatment, as well as centers with neurocritical care and neurosurgical capabilities.

recommendations.section: Organization of Prehospital and Initial Systems
recommendations.text: In regions where mobile stroke units (MSUs) are available, their use is reasonable for patients with suspected stroke, including spontaneous ICH, to enable faster diagnosis and treatment than standard ambulance transport.

recommendations.section: Organization of Prehospital and Initial Systems
recommendations.text: Training first responders in stroke evaluation, airway management, and circulatory support is reasonable for patients with suspected spontaneous ICH to detect and manage prehospital neurological deterioration.

A focused history, physical examination, and baseline laboratory workup (including CBC, PT/INR/PTT, creatinine/eGFR, glucose, troponin, ECG, toxicology screen, and inflammatory markers) are recommended on admission to characterize the hemorrhage type, identify active medical issues, and assess prognosis.

recommendations.section: Neuroimaging for ICH Diagnosis and Acute
recommendations.text: Rapid neuroimaging with CT or MRI is recommended for patients presenting with stroke-like symptoms to confirm the diagnosis of spontaneous ICH.

recommendations.section: Neuroimaging for ICH Diagnosis and Acute
recommendations.text: Serial head CT within the first 24 hours of symptom onset can be useful for patients with spontaneous ICH and/or IVH to evaluate for hemorrhage expansion.

recommendations.section: Neuroimaging for ICH Diagnosis and Acute
recommendations.text: Serial head CT can be useful for patients with spontaneous ICH and/or IVH who have a low GCS score or neurological deterioration, to evaluate for hemorrhage expansion, hydrocephalus, brain swelling, or herniation.

recommendations.section: Neuroimaging for ICH Diagnosis and Acute
recommendations.text: CTA within the first few hours of ICH onset may be reasonable to identify patients at risk for subsequent hemorrhage expansion.

recommendations.section: Neuroimaging for ICH Diagnosis and Acute
recommendations.text: Using NCCT markers of hemorrhage expansion (e.g., spot sign, blend sign, black hole sign) to identify at-risk patients may be reasonable.

Acute CTA with consideration of venography is recommended for patients with lobar ICH aged <70 years, deep/posterior fossa ICH aged <45 years, or deep/posterior fossa ICH aged 45-70 years without hypertension history, to exclude macrovascular causes or cerebral venous thrombosis.
Catheter-based intra-arterial DSA is recommended for patients with spontaneous IVH and no detectable parenchymal hemorrhage to exclude a macrovascular cause.

When CTA or MRA suggests a macrovascular cause in patients with spontaneous ICH, catheter-based intra-arterial DSA is recommended as soon as possible to confirm and manage underlying intracranial vascular malformations.

Catheter-based intra-arterial DSA is reasonable for patients with lobar ICH aged <70 years, deep/posterior fossa ICH aged <45 years, or deep/posterior fossa ICH aged 45-70 years without hypertension when noninvasive imaging (CTA/venography and MRI/MRA) is negative, to exclude a macrovascular cause.

When CTA/venography is negative in patients with spontaneous ICH, MRI and MRA are reasonable to identify a nonmacrovascular cause such as CAA, deep perforating vasculopathy, cavernous malformation, or malignancy.
Acute CTA or MRA with consideration of venography can be useful for patients with spontaneous ICH who undergo initial CT or MRI, to exclude macrovascular causes or cerebral venous thrombosis.

When initial catheter-based DSA is negative and no clear microvascular diagnosis or structural lesion is identified, a repeat DSA 3 to 6 months after ICH onset may be reasonable to detect a previously obscured vascular lesion.

For patients with spontaneous ICH requiring acute BP lowering, careful titration to achieve continuous, smooth, and sustained BP control while avoiding SBP peaks and large variability can be beneficial for functional outcomes.
Initiating acute BP treatment within 2 hours of ICH onset and reaching the target within 1 hour can be beneficial to reduce hemorrhage expansion risk and improve functional outcome.

For patients with mild to moderate spontaneous ICH presenting with SBP 150-220 mm Hg, acutely lowering SBP to a target of 140 mm Hg (maintaining 130-150 mm Hg range) is safe and may be reasonable for improving functional outcomes.
The safety and efficacy of intensive BP lowering are not well established for patients with large or severe spontaneous ICH or those requiring surgical decompression.
Acute lowering of SBP to <130 mm Hg is potentially harmful in patients with mild to moderate spontaneous ICH presenting with SBP >150 mm Hg.
Immediate discontinuation of anticoagulation and rapid reversal are recommended as soon as possible after diagnosis of anticoagulant-associated spontaneous ICH to improve survival.
4-factor PCC is recommended over FFP for patients with VKA-associated spontaneous ICH and INR >= 2.0 to achieve rapid INR correction and limit hemorrhage expansion.
Intravenous vitamin K is recommended immediately after coagulation factor replacement (PCC or other) for VKA-associated spontaneous ICH to prevent subsequent INR elevation and hemorrhage expansion.
PCC may be reasonable for patients with VKA-associated spontaneous ICH and INR 1.3-1.9 to achieve rapid INR correction and limit hemorrhage expansion.
Andexanet alfa is reasonable for patients with direct factor Xa inhibitor-associated spontaneous ICH to reverse the anticoagulant effect.
Idarucizumab is reasonable for patients with dabigatran-associated spontaneous ICH to reverse the anticoagulant effect.
4-factor PCC or activated PCC (aPCC) may be considered for patients with direct factor Xa inhibitor-associated spontaneous ICH to improve hemostasis.

Activated charcoal may be reasonable for patients with dabigatran- or factor Xa inhibitor-associated spontaneous ICH when the DOAC was ingested within the previous few hours, to prevent further drug absorption.
When idarucizumab is unavailable, aPCC or PCCs may be considered for patients with dabigatran-associated spontaneous ICH to improve hemostasis.
When idarucizumab is unavailable, renal replacement therapy may be considered for patients with dabigatran-associated spontaneous ICH to reduce circulating dabigatran concentration.
Intravenous protamine is reasonable for patients with UFH-associated spontaneous ICH to reverse the anticoagulant effect of heparin.
Intravenous protamine may be considered for patients with LMWH-associated spontaneous ICH to partially reverse the anticoagulant effect.
Platelet transfusion might be considered for patients with aspirin-associated spontaneous ICH who require emergency neurosurgery, to reduce postoperative bleeding and mortality.
The effectiveness of desmopressin, with or without platelet transfusions, to reduce hematoma expansion in patients with antiplatelet-associated spontaneous ICH is uncertain.
Platelet transfusions are potentially harmful and are not recommended for patients with aspirin-associated spontaneous ICH who are not scheduled for emergency surgery.
The effectiveness of recombinant factor VIIa for improving functional outcome in patients with spontaneous ICH (with or without the spot sign) is unclear.
The effectiveness of tranexamic acid (TXA) for improving functional outcome in patients with spontaneous ICH (with or without spot sign, black hole sign, or blend sign) is not well established.
Care in a specialized stroke unit with a multidisciplinary team is recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH to improve outcomes and reduce mortality.
Provision of care at centers capable of delivering the full range of high-acuity ICH management and expertise is recommended to improve outcomes.

Transfer to a center with neurosurgical capabilities is recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH and clinical hydrocephalus requiring definitive management (e.g., EVD placement and monitoring) to reduce mortality.
Care delivery by multidisciplinary teams trained in neurological assessment is recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH to improve outcomes.

Appropriate life-sustaining therapies (airway, ventilation, hemodynamic support) are recommended before inter-hospital transport for patients with spontaneous ICH who lack adequate airway protection, gas exchange, or hemodynamic stability.
For patients with spontaneous ICH who do not require ICU admission at presentation, initial care in a stroke unit rather than a general ward is reasonable to reduce mortality and improve outcomes.
A neuro-specific ICU is reasonable over a general ICU for patients with moderate to severe spontaneous ICH, IVH, hydrocephalus, or infratentorial hemorrhage to improve outcomes and reduce mortality.
Transfer to centers with neurosurgical capabilities might be reasonable for patients with IVH or infratentorial ICH to improve outcomes.
Transfer to centers with neurosurgical capabilities may be reasonable for patients with larger supratentorial ICH to improve outcomes.

recommendations.section: Prevention and Management of Acute Medical
recommendations.text: Standardized protocols and/or order sets are recommended for the care of patients with spontaneous ICH to reduce disability and mortality.

recommendations.section: Prevention and Management of Acute Medical
recommendations.text: A formal dysphagia screening protocol is recommended before initiating oral intake in patients with spontaneous ICH to reduce disability and pneumonia risk.

recommendations.section: Prevention and Management of Acute Medical
recommendations.text: Continuous cardiac monitoring for the first 24 to 72 hours of admission is reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH to detect arrhythmias and new cardiac ischemia.

recommendations.section: Prevention and Management of Acute Medical
recommendations.text: Diagnostic laboratory and radiographic testing for infection on admission and throughout hospitalization is reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH to improve outcomes.
Intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) starting on the day of diagnosis is recommended for VTE prophylaxis in nonambulatory patients with spontaneous ICH.
Low-dose UFH or LMWH can be useful for nonambulatory patients with spontaneous ICH to reduce the risk of pulmonary embolism.

Initiating low-dose UFH or LMWH prophylaxis at 24 to 48 hours from ICH onset may be reasonable in nonambulatory patients to optimize the balance between thrombosis prevention and hemorrhage expansion risk.
Graduated compression stockings (knee-high or thigh-high) alone are not beneficial for VTE prophylaxis in nonambulatory patients with spontaneous ICH.
Temporary placement of a retrievable IVC filter is reasonable as a bridge to anticoagulation for patients with acute spontaneous ICH and proximal DVT who are not yet candidates for anticoagulation.
Delaying therapeutic UFH or LMWH for 1 to 2 weeks after ICH onset might be considered for patients with acute spontaneous ICH and proximal DVT or PE.
Frequent neurological assessments (including GCS) by ED nurses are recommended during the early hyperacute phase of spontaneous ICH to detect changes in neurological status or level of consciousness.
Frequent neurological assessments in the ICU and stroke unit for up to 72 hours of admission are reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH to detect early neurological deterioration.
Specialized nurse stroke competencies can be effective in improving outcomes and reducing mortality for patients with spontaneous ICH.
Serum glucose monitoring is recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH to prevent the harmful effects of both hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia.
Treatment of hypoglycemia (<40-60 mg/dL or <2.2-3.3 mmol/L) is recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH to reduce mortality.
Treatment of moderate to severe hyperglycemia (>180-200 mg/dL or >10.0-11.1 mmol/L) is reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH to improve outcomes.
Pharmacological treatment of elevated temperature may be reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH to improve functional outcomes.
The usefulness of therapeutic hypothermia (<35 degrees C / 95 degrees F) for decreasing peri-ICH edema is unclear.
Antiseizure drugs are recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH who have impaired consciousness and confirmed electrographic seizures to reduce morbidity.
Antiseizure drugs are recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH and clinical seizures to improve functional outcomes and prevent brain injury from prolonged or recurrent seizure activity.

Continuous EEG monitoring (at least 24 hours) is reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH and unexplained or fluctuating mental status changes or clinical suspicion for seizures, to diagnose electrographic seizures and epileptiform discharges.
Prophylactic antiseizure medication is not beneficial for patients with spontaneous ICH who have no evidence of seizures with regard to functional outcomes, long-term seizure control, or mortality.
Ventricular drainage is recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH or IVH and hydrocephalus contributing to decreased level of consciousness, to reduce mortality.
ICP monitoring and treatment might be considered for patients with moderate to severe spontaneous ICH or IVH with reduced level of consciousness to reduce mortality and improve outcomes.
The efficacy of early prophylactic hyperosmolar therapy for improving outcomes in patients with spontaneous ICH is not well established.
Bolus hyperosmolar therapy may be considered for patients with spontaneous ICH as a temporizing measure to reduce ICP.
Corticosteroids are not recommended for the treatment of elevated ICP in patients with spontaneous ICH.

Minimally invasive hematoma evacuation (endoscopic or stereotactic aspiration, with or without thrombolytic use) can be useful to reduce mortality compared with medical management alone for patients with supratentorial ICH >20-30 mL and GCS 5-12.

When hematoma evacuation is being considered for patients with supratentorial ICH >20-30 mL and GCS 5-12, selecting minimally invasive evacuation over conventional craniotomy may be reasonable to improve functional outcomes.

The effectiveness of minimally invasive hematoma evacuation (endoscopic or stereotactic aspiration, with or without thrombolytic use) for improving functional outcomes in patients with supratentorial ICH >20-30 mL and GCS 5-12 is uncertain.
EVD is recommended over medical management alone for patients with spontaneous ICH, large IVH, and impaired level of consciousness to reduce mortality.

Minimally invasive IVH evacuation with EVD plus thrombolytic is safe and reasonable compared with EVD alone for patients with GCS >3 and primary IVH or IVH extension from supratentorial ICH <30 mL requiring EVD, to reduce mortality.

The effectiveness of minimally invasive IVH evacuation with EVD plus thrombolytic for improving functional outcomes is uncertain for patients with GCS >3 and primary IVH or IVH extension from supratentorial ICH <30 mL requiring EVD.
The efficacy of EVD for improving functional outcomes is not well established in patients with severe spontaneous ICH, large IVH, and impaired level of consciousness.

The usefulness of minimally invasive IVH evacuation with neuroendoscopy plus EVD, with or without thrombolytic, to improve functional outcomes and reduce permanent shunt dependence is uncertain for patients with supratentorial ICH <30 mL and IVH requiring EVD.
The usefulness of craniotomy for hemorrhage evacuation to improve functional outcomes or mortality is uncertain for most patients with moderate or greater supratentorial spontaneous ICH.
Craniotomy for hematoma evacuation might be considered as a lifesaving measure in patients with supratentorial ICH who are clinically deteriorating.

Immediate surgical evacuation of the hemorrhage, with or without EVD, is recommended over medical management alone for patients with cerebellar ICH who are neurologically deteriorating, have brainstem compression and/or hydrocephalus from ventricular obstruction, or have cerebellar ICH volume >= 15 mL, to reduce mortality.

Decompressive craniectomy with or without hematoma evacuation may be considered to reduce mortality in patients with supratentorial ICH who are comatose, have large hematomas with significant midline shift, or have elevated ICP refractory to medical management.

The effectiveness of decompressive craniectomy with or without hematoma evacuation for improving functional outcomes is uncertain in patients with supratentorial ICH who are comatose, have large hematomas with significant midline shift, or have refractory elevated ICP.
A baseline hemorrhage severity score is recommended as part of the initial evaluation for patients with spontaneous ICH to provide an overall measure of clinical severity.
A baseline severity score might be reasonable as a general framework for communication with patients and their caregivers about prognosis.
A baseline severity score alone is not recommended as the sole basis for forecasting individual prognosis or deciding to limit life-sustaining treatment in patients with spontaneous ICH.

For patients with spontaneous ICH who lack preexisting documented wishes to limit life-sustaining therapy, aggressive care with postponement of new DNAR orders or withdrawal of support until at least the second full day of hospitalization is reasonable to decrease mortality and improve functional outcome.

A shared decision-making model between surrogates and physicians is reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH who cannot fully participate in medical decision-making, to align care with patient wishes and improve surrogate satisfaction.

Limiting other medical and surgical interventions solely on the basis of DNAR status, without explicit patient or surrogate direction, is associated with increased mortality in patients with spontaneous ICH.
Multidisciplinary rehabilitation with regular team meetings and discharge planning is recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH to improve functional outcome and reduce morbidity and mortality.
Early supported discharge is beneficial for patients with mild to moderate spontaneous ICH to increase the likelihood of living at home at 3 months.

Early rehabilitation beginning 24 to 48 hours after onset (including ADL training, stretching, and functional task training) may be considered for patients with moderately severe spontaneous ICH to improve functional outcome and reduce mortality.
Fluoxetine therapy is not effective for enhancing poststroke functional status in patients with spontaneous ICH who do not have depression.
Very early and intense mobilization within the first 24 hours after spontaneous ICH is associated with a lower likelihood of good recovery.
Evidence-based treatments including psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy are recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH and moderate to severe depression to reduce depressive symptoms.
Administration of validated depression and anxiety screening tools in the postacute period is recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH to identify poststroke depression and anxiety.
A cognitive screening tool in the postacute period is recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH to identify cognitive impairment and dementia.
Referral for cognitive therapy is reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH and cognitive impairment to improve cognitive outcomes.
Continuation or initiation of SSRIs after spontaneous ICH can be beneficial for patients with preexisting or new mood disorders requiring pharmacotherapy.
Cholinesterase inhibitors or memantine might be considered for patients with spontaneous ICH and cognitive impairment to improve cognitive outcomes.

When assessing recurrent ICH risk for prognostication or management decisions, it is reasonable to incorporate the following risk factors: lobar location of the initial ICH, older age, presence/number/lobar location of MRI microbleeds, cortical superficial siderosis on MRI, poorly controlled hypertension, Asian or Black race, and apolipoprotein E epsilon-2 or epsilon-4 alleles.
Long-term BP control is recommended for patients with spontaneous ICH to prevent hemorrhage recurrence.
Targeting a long-term SBP of <130 mm Hg and DBP of <80 mm Hg is reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH to prevent hemorrhage recurrence.

Early resumption of anticoagulation is reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH who have conditions placing them at high thromboembolic risk (e.g., mechanical heart valve, LVAD) to prevent thromboembolic complications.

Resumption of antiplatelet therapy may be reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH and an indication for antiplatelet treatment, based on weighing thromboembolic prevention benefits against recurrent hemorrhage risk.

Resumption of anticoagulation may be considered for patients with nonvalvular AF and spontaneous ICH to prevent thromboembolic events and reduce all-cause mortality, based on individualized benefit-risk assessment.

When anticoagulation is to be restarted in patients with AF and spontaneous ICH, initiation at 7 to 8 weeks after ICH may be considered after weighing patient-specific factors to optimize the benefit-risk balance.
Left atrial appendage closure may be considered for patients with AF and spontaneous ICH who are deemed ineligible for anticoagulation, to reduce thromboembolic risk.

The risks and benefits of statin therapy on ICH outcomes and recurrence relative to overall cardiovascular event prevention are uncertain for patients with spontaneous ICH and an established statin indication.
Regular long-term use of NSAIDs is potentially harmful for patients with spontaneous ICH because of the increased risk of recurrent ICH.
Lifestyle modification is reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH to help lower blood pressure.
Avoiding heavy alcohol consumption is reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH to reduce hypertension and ICH recurrence risk.
Lifestyle modification including supervised training and counseling may be reasonable for patients with spontaneous ICH to improve functional recovery.
Psychosocial education for caregivers can be beneficial to increase activity level, participation, and quality of life for patients with spontaneous ICH.
Practical support and training for caregivers is reasonable to improve standing balance in patients with spontaneous ICH.

recommendations.section: Primary ICH Prevention in Individuals With High-
recommendations.text: When considering primary ICH prevention, incorporating available MRI findings such as cerebral microbleed burden or cortical superficial siderosis into shared decision-making about stroke prevention treatment plans may be reasonable.
